Really. His happiest day! Can you tell us about that day, Mr. Fleury? Fleury smiles, looks out at the class.  KINGDOM 8/18/06 4.

I sure can. That was December 4th and that was the day that we spent the whole day in the hospital waiting for this guy right here to come out of Kevin’s mom’s tummy. And we waited and waited but he wouldn’t come and we kept waiting and finally the doctor said ‘OK...he’s not gonna come out on his own so we got to go get him.’ And well, Fleury stops, checks in with Miss Ross.
Can I tell this story?

Go for it. RONALD Fleury So they take her and put her ona special bed and they give her some medicine so she doesn’t feel any pain then they take out this tiny little knife and make a tiny little cut right here in her tummy. The kids are mesmerized...
Then what happened? RONALD Fleury Then the doctor put her hands way up into Kevin’s mom’s tummy. WAY IN! And then you know what they did? A little girl, LU LU: WIDE EYED
What did they do?

They started to pull and pull and pull... they had something in there and it started coming and they were pulling and the doctor all of the sudden said “STOP!” The class is frozen. Fleury has them.  KINGDOM 8/18/06 5.

They stopped pulling and the doctor looked up at me and said ‘Hey, Mr. Fleury - you ready to have your world rocked?’ And I just stared at her and she pulled this little head up out of that belly. And it was him. His head. And I looked down at him and screamed “Kevin!!” And he looked down at me and screamed “"Daddy!!” The kids are howling!

Played on the only stretch of green grass visible from this vantage.

I like that, “Sun is shining...” A tight smile from Haytham. The other Officers are checking the inside of the Rover n They nod to Haytham, Haytham hands the ID back to her. Windows rolls up. Lift-gate goes up. Range Rover pulls aw navigating the zig-zag jersey barriers.

Hang up the phone. If they're not ready now, no words will change it.

(back the Batter) Ready for my knuckle-curve? The Batter just stays focused as the Pitcher tosses a hig lob. Batter smacks the ball a mile high, deep to left. Th teammates of the plump-pink Boy on third:

The muted reaction to the dropped ball. The whole Family, save the youngest Grandson, intently focused on two Offic walking up to that Police Land Cruiser parked in the midd of the road, well inside the compound: no blinks now. The youngest still enthralled by the softball game, the cheers, the running, the shorts and t-shirts. Don't stop watching the game.
Noises from the softball game close again. Track these tw Officers on foot walking toward the Police Land Cruiser a shift change: nonchalant but quick.
The Driver eyeing the two approaching Officers: something about them. Uniforms wrinkled, one with a full beard. Dri turns to his Partner, in Arabic:

You have a copy of the duty rost- -POP-POP-POP before the Driver finishes. The Officers on rapid-firing 9MM pistols. The Driver and Passenger hit multiple times instantly, crumble lifeless in their seats before anyone has time to process the sounds, link them t attack. I said keep watching the game.

Then points at the Officer in the Driver’s seat: SERGEANT HAYTHAM (CONT’D)

Game forgotten. Parents up, screaming for loved ones, mov fast toward the parking lot. The Middle-Eastern Officer t has been watching the game hustles onto the field, next t the Pitcher, waves people toward him. Gathering but spora gun-fire in very near distance.
(accented English)

The youngest grandson’s wide-eyed face. Then we see the Grandfather’s right-hand slide down the other side of his youngest Grandson’s face, coming to rest on his other tem making sure he’s still watching the Softball diamond now. Grandfather’s right hand: missing an index and middle fin

Located behind straight-a-way center field, at the nexus four fields. Panicked women walking dogs. Frozen. A Police Land Cruise with bullet-scarred windows roars around the corner. Stop near the women. They smile: cavalry to the rescue. -another Police Land Cruiser from nowhere hammers their Driver’s side. Vicious. The Passenger is launched out his window, head-first into the curb. Both vehicles smoke- screech. Just the youngest Grandson’s horrified eyes: he had no ch but to see it all, carnage painted permanently. His face still held tight between his Grandfather’s hands. In Arab
Our Time is not a peaceful one. God has left it to us to make it so. Hold on those deep, young, brown eyes. Those young brown eyes finally blink.

Everyone eats snacks that the Fleurys brought. Kevin’s th center of attention. Fleury’s passing out juice boxes. Fleury’s cell phone vibrates. TIGHT ON THE ID: 911. Fleur mid-juice-pass, answering his phone at the same time. Kevin looks to his Dad, already grimacing. Fleury walks a from the kids.

When?

Fran, I’m rollin’ right now. Let me call you back: I_gotta ring bells  KINGDOM 8/18/06 13.

(smile) Where he’s from in South Carolina that’s called fine-dining, Bud.

You gonna go see him?  28 KINGDOM 8/18/06 14.

(to Lyla) Can you get a ride? She nods yes. Miss Ross nearby, surprised by this:
Where’s your husband going?
Ex-husband, and God knows. Then a wave of fear ripples across her face. She hesitate then calls after him:

Ronald turns, gives a little Cheshire grin, puts the phon back up to his ear. EXT. AL-RAHMAH HOUSING COMPOUND BLAST SITES —- EVENING 28 The shattered softball diamond and parking lot. (immediately behind) Fran. You gotta stand Big Man... Fran turns to find REX BURR: 5’'7” fireplug. A long silen Fran points to the hat:

You gotta stand, Big Man. Fran does. Wipes his hands on his pants. Slack-jaw hopele The first moments in what will be weeks of reverse- engineering the murders of unknown dozens. Slowly lift up and hold on Al-Rahmah as it burns. Black s and flame pour skyward from the site of the coup de grace explosion. Massive crater. Screams. Chaos postcard.

Startling quiet in contrast. AGENTS cluster beneath 32-in Televisions suspended from the ceiling. Tuned to Al-Jazee CNN, BBC, etc. Most eyes focus on the double-bloody scoop from CNN. Volume low:

JANET MAYES, 29 years-old, stifles a sob in the front row Fleury steps from behind the podium, puts a hand gently o Janet’s shoulder, leans in and whispers something no one Janet hears. Whatever his words, they give back her composure. She nods. RONALD FLEURY (CONT’D) So was Rex Burr from State. Fleury lets the news absorb as he steps back to the podiu No one says a thing. Fleury lifts his eyes again, real trouble maintaining control... RONALD FLEURY (CONT’D) Fran was the best among us...we’ll feel this loss the rest of our days... (beat, moment to regroup) Grant, take stabs at bomb sizes. GRANT SYKES. 50 years-old. Virginia State Trooper before joining the FBI. Law-and-order formidable: sharp-smart Charlottesville accent. Studies the images for a beat...

From the craters, looks like they used a High Explosive... possibly military grade: can’t fit that much TNT into a vest. 20, 30 pounds of PETN: they got it. Semtex or C-4: they could get it. The third there, God knows...that crater looks like a plane dropped a 500-pounder...
Obviously a secondary blast after the initial devices used to lure first responders to the scene. Don’t know anything about where or what it was yet.

This is how they do it. ADAM LEAVITT. 34 years-old, sought-after Investigator. There’s a constant, intense grind to this guy, a mind and mouth incapable of quiet. He paces around the room, then eagle-eyes the bomb images... starts surge-scrawling crud diagrams of the blast site on a piece of loose leaf. Feel more like nervous doodling than work. Not looking up from drawing:  KINGDOM 8/18/06 19.
I already know the answer, but any chance in Hell we get to go over there, use our hands?
If you already know the answer Adam, why ask the question? Fleury circles Leavitt's name on the roster. Leavitt neve stops drawing.

We’re not seeing this kind of planning and execution anywhere else...these ain’t hot-wired artillery shells waiting for Humvees to roll by. (pointing at the screens) These hits are coordinated: planning, timing, and big, broad- daylight balls-

Fleury looks over to AGENT #1 on immediate right, an egg-head type with a big binder in fr of him. Everyone’s eyes follow. Agent #1 flips quickly through the binder, back-and-forth, searching. Fleury cro his name off of his roster. Then:
Yes. At least the first parts of the attacks. Everyone smells it: that’s big -- more proof these attack are being carried out by one, very skilled Terror Cell.

Same thing. Followed by machine gun crews. Collect and kill.

This is not new in concept. It is new in scope. It’s bigger. Very sophisticated. Command and control was flawless. They found the largest kill zone they could and they did it... they did it by being patient.
Any rumors or confirmations of uniforms being used in the other two attacks? Fleury circles Mayes’ name on the ERT roster.
(from memory) No. I know this is the first for that.

That’s ‘worst case scenario’ if you’re still asking for my stab, Sir. A crew who can build bombs this big, with this level of eyes- on control and detonation coordination... has access to Saudi uniforms now...I mean...Baby Jesus.
Anyone take credit? Fleury checks from his notes.
Abu Hamza. Saudi Al-Qaeda. Bin- Laden-wanna-be. We know he was in Afghanistan, then moved to Iraq. Now he seems to have come home. He’s clearly becoming increasingly active...
If it is Hamza, he’s definitely turning up the volume over there. (MORE )

Not to beat a dead horse, Sir, but if there was ever a time to get boots on Saudi sand... Sykes studies Leavitt with what is best described as substantial skepticism. Fleury circles Sykes’ name on his roster.

They can’t afford to appear as if they are losing any kind of control. They lose control over their country, their people...then they risk losing control over the oil. They won’t let us in. No way. Fleury’s P.0O.V.: His open folder on the podium. A memo printed on Department of State letterhead. Pulls the memo reads it aloud, calm laced with rage.

From the State Department, one hour ago: ‘We are in agreement with the Saudi security assessment that any additional American presence on Kingdom soil represents reckless risk. Therefore it is the Secretary of State’s position that only after the situation has been evaluated and contained, should the Federal Bureau of Investigation activate Rapid Deployment.’ (folding the memo) The National Security Advisor and the Attorney General agreed. (beat) I’m going to get us access. Keep your go bags hot. It’s gonna come fast. Leavitt stares at Fleury as he moves fast out of the room

INT. SAUDI NATIONAL GUARD PRISON —- INTERROGATION ROOM 34 Al-Ghazi walks back into the room with the shirts, lays t down on the table in front of the General -- all business

You were injured when you used your vehicle to protect your country. Do you understand? Al-Ghazi moves in, begins uncuffing Haytham’s bloody-raw wrists, hard-eyeing Malik the whole time. These men clear don’t like each other.

Formed the plan up here: saw everything he could hit. (beat) Way too pretty a’ plan to have been fully hatched on just one visit. He came here a couple times. Al-Ghazi quiet for a long while. Then he reciprocates:

The man who did this is a Saudi - this place, this neighborhood... if foreigners were up here, someone would say something. Fleury looks over to the two dozen LOCALS peering out wit suspicion at them on the rooftop.
I see.

Nobody’s talking. Here, many people love Hamza - they think of him like Bin Laden. Like your Robin Hood. Fleury smiles small at whatever just passed between them. Ghazi stays stoic, then looks straight at Fleury:
+ eH  KINGDOM 8/18/06 82.
A man who thinks of something like this ...while maybe his family played around him... scares me more than I have words to express. Shaytan...
(refocusing) Two big answers in two small minutes. Imagine if we had a couple days together. Al-Ghazi pauses.

I’m sure the General is good guy...and I’m just as sure he’s no Investigator. Al-Ghazi stands still, silent. Fleury reaches into his pocket. Reveals the detonator to Al-Ghazi. Al-Ghazi reach to take it. Fleury holds it for a BEAT...
Let me help you. He hands the detonator to Al-Ghazi. Al-Ghazi now pockets A BEAT...
We break now: too hot to work outdoors. Then we will leave for the Palace.
And I imagine that will run until sundown?
(beat) I had televisions delivered to your quarters to pass the downtime. Fleury just nods back.
Miss Mayes will not attend this evening. Men only. Fleury looks over to Janet. Hurt, yet extremely defiant, looks ready to attack anything that comes near her.  83 84 85 KINGDOM 8/18/06 83.
You want to tell her that?
Cobra gunships covering the convoy as it blurs past polic checkpoint after police checkpoint. Intersections shut do Bracketed front and back by Saudi Humvees.

Al-Ghazi in the passenger seat, hand on the stock of his 5: again searching for threats. Our team in back, freshly scrubbed, collared-Polos as formal as anyone thought to p Team frustration has evolved into angry acceptance. The convoy zipping alongside a wall now: desert-orange in color, twelve-feet high, blue ottoman tiles running the length of the wall’s horizontal center-line.
We're here. The helicopters peel off at steep angles, the sound of th rotors reverberating in your chest. Leavitt watching them
Big wall.

It’s a big palace. INT. PRINCE BIN KHALED’S PALACE - DAY 85 Majlis - a Saudi political ceremony in which Saudi citize and local politicians (most aristocratic and exclusive) a permitted a brief audience with the Prince. A bizarre receiving line of sorts. Our team moves through a massive marble hallway towards t ceremony.
How many Princes are there?
Over 5000.
They all get palaces this big?
Some get bigger.
Who pays for all this?
General Motors, Ford, Chevrolet...
Hey, man - I drive a Hybrid.
(a beat...) The Prince will ask you about your flight, the accommodations...lite subjects. If he offers you the chance to hold his Raptors, don’t flinch: it’s a compliment.

(to Grant: genuine worry) What’s a Raptor? Damon Schmidt appears. INT. PRINCE BIN KHALED’S PALACE —- LATER 85A The Prince sits on a sea of pillows. There are several sm flat screens playing business reports, CNN and Al-Jazeera Seen from behind the Prince: everyone but Leavitt standin next to faces we’ve never seen. The table holds six gold serving platters. Enough food to kill a famine, tended by frenzy of servants. Sykes puts a hand over his cup to stop the constant tea r fill. Leavitt stands to the Prince’s left, thick leather glove his hand, a falcon perched on it. Leavitt holds it away f the rest of his body like he’s already made peace with lo the arm. Servants hold three others close-by.
His talons slice bone.
Super.  KINGDOM 8/18/06 85.
That’s my most prolific Hunter. I’m trying to teach his friends there by example, but I fear it’s something you’re born with or not. Do you agree, Mr. Ronald? Innate or not at all?
I do.

(nodding: I could tell) What have you seen so far of our Kingdom? -- and know I can arrange tours anywhere within our borders. When I bull-rush our hosts you’ll know it: In his quiet, amidst-the-bullets tone:

I’ve seen that the man who planned the worst crime in your Kingdom's history is without a doubt Saudi... Pin-drop silence in response to Fleury murdering the Prin “lite subjects,” his attempt to extend the gilded circle- by offering tours. Bin Khaled’s face sinks to gray again after the excited pink of talking about his Falcons. His slowly moves back over his stomach: Napoleon's ulcers. As Fleury speaks, people unconsciously put their tea-cups do look up at him with wide-eyes. RONALD FLEURY (CONT’D) --and that if you walk 300 kilometers from the compound, you will find a rooftop where the attacks were planned. I’ve seen that the person in this room “born with it” is right there... (points at a gawking Al- Ghazi) Everything I just said came from Colonel Al-Ghazi: his observations of the scene while he was protecting us. And I think you’re absolutely right Sir: that kind of instinct can’t be taught: not to Falcons. Definitely not to SANG Generals. Innate or not at all. (beat) You want the murder to stop as much as I do. Let us help.
The Prince stares at Fleury, cataloguing everything Fleur just said. Stands. In Arabic:

Colonel Al-Ghazi, a word. As the Prince walks out with Al-Ghazi, he signals another corps of servants to serve another round of cups: coffee. Dinner over. A servant takes the Falcon from Leavitt just he was starting to smile at it. Fleury sips his coffee. Schmidt and Sykes approach.
That was impressive.
Think it will work?
Yeah. Maybe. I mean, you can only play the “I’m going to the press card” like three more times. So, maybe.
They’re paranoid and overly self- protective.

They aren’t protecting anyone. There’s no conspiracy. They’re just terrified. Finally. The Saudis have finally seen the Monsters they helped create, because those Monsters have come home. And if Saudis don’t catch Saudi Monsters, that’s the end. Fleury opens his mouth to interrupt.

(right through Fleury’s attempt to speak) And that end could come double- quick if they let the US “Shaytan” catch those Monsters for them. (Fleury silent, gets it) Because that’s what the Saudi on the street suspects: the only thing keeping the Royal Family upright is American evil.  KINGDOM 8/18/06 87.
That’s dead on accurate. Very impressive. That’s why they’re making it hard on us, and that’s why he wants to help ‘em turn the screws.
They can have every shred of credit-
-you see the slums on the way in?
Yeah.
See that even though their homes are falling down, they had satellite dishes bolted on?
Yeah...
Everyone already knows you’re here. Credit? If the Saudis cracked this Cell while these servants were pouring coffee, Al-Jazeera still leads the story with your Team.
Have you been to the crime-scene?
No-
-if you had, you’d see the evil work of real Talent. The kind that doesn’t stop until it’s forced.
And the path to Hell is paved with good intentions.
You having fun?
(genuine smile) Beats hell outta visa-stamping. (smile vanishing) (MORE )
You’re on an island. I hope you know how to get off.
By catching Abu Hamza. Raising his coffee, toasting Fleury’s cup:
Then here’s to you. Let’s bet: when this Colonel Al-Ghazi comes out, he’s in-charge of the investigation -if so, you set me up on a date with Janet Mayes.
100 m.p.h. Semi-grins from the Team: how the fuck did he that? Al-Ghazi on a cell, rattling orders in excited Arab
«-. every investigator on-scene by midnight, 50 more portable lights, three more pumps-
(to Leavitt) Do me a favor and tell Janet that she and Damon Schmidt got a date when he gets back to the States. Al-Ghazi points into darkness...

The rules still stand. (beat) But tomorrow will be a new day. INT. UNKNOWN LOCATION —- SAME MOMENT 87 TIGHT ON blasting caps, military detonators, nails, wing- nuts, bolts, jacks, marbles... young hands feed lengths o detonating wire through pre-drilled holes on a wooden cov The cover is attached to the box with nails and a rubber mallet: no sparks. The wires are braided into one, clippe a lead on a servo-motor attached to the box-top. A vehicle is being fitted with tire guards and heavy-duty crash bumpers - all as a man quietly talks.  88 KINGDOM 8/18/06 89. WIDEN to reveal the MAN, being VIDEOTAPED: foretelling of threats, face obscured by his head wrap. Several other ME watch and listen. TIGHT ON the man’s eyes. REVEAL PHOTOS on a nearby table: Al-Rahmah compound, Fleury with Al-Ghazi, Leavitt and May Sykes and Haytham.
Half-assed gardening party. Al-Ghazi worked through the night, hasn’t slept since we last saw him. Looks like it.
From now on, any evidence you find you hand over. Al-Ghazi smiles...
I’m “all ears,” Special Agent Fleury.
We should start with the dead shooters.
They had no identification on them. Fingerprints and dental have come up empty.
Can we photograph all three of them? Couple hundred copies each...
No problem.

Good. If it’s OK with you, I’d like to suggest we split up as follows... Sykes and Leavitt can’t help small smiles. Finally gettin work.  aso KINGDOM 8/18/06 89A. EXT. BLAST SITE - MORNING aso Sykes climbs down into the mud hole.
(from the crater) Fellas, what we want to do is get this water out of here... see what’s really going on. Understand? No reaction from Saudi police

C-VIN hunting--Data Plates-- Something drivable blew up. That’s pretty obvious. Feels like ANFO to me, boys--Ammonium Nitrate Fuel Oil. lLet’s dry this hole and see if we can’t figure what she was. Gotta pump?
+e HH OH
Grant at the Crater. Three brand-new industrial-sized pum draining it. 30 Police INVESTIGATORS watch Sykes.
(to the Saudis) Got to get a little dirty, people. Crawl up in it. Make deep contact. You get that? Dead, confused stares from the Saudis into the mud hole.. Sykes happy as a pig in shit.
Get nasty, dirty, filthy. He smiles, watches another Officer write Saudi translatio on the stainless-steel paint cans into which you load evidence: shrapnel, soil, DNA, shells, etc.
A JUNIOR OFFICER double-times it to Al-Ghazi with a stack photos: Rough head-shots of the three dead SHOOTERS. Fleu takes some, hands the rest back to Al-Ghazi.

Have him pass these out to the compound security. See if anybody knows them. Fleury, Leavitt, and Al-Ghazi walk past the Land Cruiser Haytham took out. 15 Police INVESTIGATORS on-scene: Leavi stops, drops his bag. Al-Ghazi introduces him to the Offi in-charge. Leavitt opens his evidence kit. A couple of Police can’t but sneak a peek, checking out what the American’s got inside.
Fleury stands with Al-Ghazi back in the Ripon home.
Would you mind doing one more thing for me?  KINGDOM 8/18/06 91.
No, Sir. Fleury pulls out the photographs.
Could you tell me if you recognize any of these men? Fleury puts the three photographs down on the dining room table: not pretty pictures. Earl and Janine study the pho
..-Horrible. A few moments, then:
I don’t know any of them. Fleury thinks a minute. Looks outside.
I’m just wondering. That chair out side. Looks like it gets a lot of wear. Looks comfortable.
That my mom’s chair.
See, that’s exactly what I was thinking. I’m guessing she spends a lot of time sitting outside?
All day.
She must pretty much see it all. Right?
She does.
Where is she?
She’s sleeping. Pause: Fleury slow nods, then...  KINGDOM 8/18/06 92.
Let’s wake her up.
Maddy up at the dinning room table, looking down at the photos.
I’ve seen him.
Where? Maddy thinking...
Like, a week ago. Twice I’ve seen him. Watering...With the garden crews. I remember he was wearing a Liza Minnelli T-shirt. I thought that was funny.
What about the others?
(closer examination) No. Just him. I remember the T- shirt. I remember thinking it was odd...?
What, the Liza Minelli shirt?
No. I do think Liza Minelli’s gone odd, but that wasn’t it.
What was odd?
He was a Saudi. The gardener.
Yeah.
Saudis, like Americans, don’t do manual labor. Blowing leaves is beneath them.  92
93 KINGDOM 8/18/06 93. Fleury looks to Al-Ghazi for confirmation. Al-Ghazi nods.
(to Maddy) Thank you. Fleury and Al-Ghazi start to leave.
Who is he? Fleury looks back to Earl.
That’s one of the many things we’re trying to find out...
Al-Ghazi gives the photo of the IDENTIFIED SHOOTER to an waiting outside.
Find out if he worked with the gardeners. The aide takes the photo, starts walking away.
Freaked, the aide about jumps out of his skin...starts running.
Sykes has a SAUDI WORK CREW digging in the hole, pulling pieces of charred metal. He is slowly laying out the piec and studying them like a puzzle, trying to figure out wha the hell blew up.
Janet and Haytham approach a 2000 square-foot M.A.S.H. Te attached to refrigeration units.  94 95 KINGDOM 8/18/06 94.
SANG OFFICERS look down at the Americans, dead eyed, watc them work.

The Muslim dead wrapped in white linen according to the Sunna. Western bodies lie separated from Arabs. A Saudi TECHNICIAN blankly hands Janet and Haytham lab coats to c the cold. Three Police OFFICERS in the tent with them: Watching Janet. Haytham is looking uncomfortable as if he is embarrassed be seen with the American woman.

Fleury knocks at Aaron Jackson's door. A pause, the peep darkens. A longer pause, then the door opens. Aaron Jacks doesn’t look any better. Same shirt. Packed boxes. Suit cases. Jackson is clearly getting out Dodge.
(beat) How are your Sons? Jackson's eyes shrink-wrapped in tears. After a long sile with no answer, Fleury hands him a sheet of paper:
That’s the name of a clinical psychologist. Works with Embassy kids...apparently very good at explaining violence-
-what do you know about what my kids need? What they saw? What the rest of their lives might be like?

(beat) I thought maybe your Boys...without their Mom anymore...might ask you why sometime...  KINGDOM 8/18/06 95. Aaron Jackson begins shaking his head yes. Tears flow fre sorrow and gratitude. He hangs on to Fleury’s hand for a long time. Silent apologies.
I will find the man responsible for the death of your wife. We're close.
(beat) Tomorrow it’1ll be somebody else's wife. Fleury quiet.

Then tomorrow I’1l come back. Fleury turns his head: Al-Ghazi approaches on the next la down with three JUNIOR OFFICERS. Fleury nods goodbye to Jackson. Fleury approaches Al-Ghazi, holds up the Shooter’s photo.
The gardener. We know who he is. He’s on several watch lists. Fleury - a slight nod of satisfaction.
We know where he lives?
We will very soon.
You don’t seem very excited.
These are always the easy ones to catch. Rarely does it lead to the planners. (beat) I want to take you somewhere.
Where?
To someone who may be able to help us catch Hamza.  96 97 98 KINGDOM 8/18/06 96.

Ten Police Investigators in the crater with Grant. Outsid the crater: pieces of vehicles laid out outside: 1/2 of a door, 1/4 of a front axle, bits of engine. Five feet away from that: stacks of bagged evidence, two dozen evidence containers. Sykes clambers out of the hole, streaks of re-animated mu where sweat streams out of his hairline, mad-dashing for chin. A chunk of metal in one hand, something small in th other: a marble. He drops it in the appropriate cannister then steps to a chunk of metal: one half of an alternator Sykes stares down at the pieces of completely mangled met He studies a piece of twisted, half-melted iron. Thinking He walks over to a second larger piece of twisted metal. Starts trying to fit the two pieces...like a puzzle.

head_text.subj: INT. MOBILE FIELD MORGUE, PRESENT DAY

text: The dead, oblong faces of the dog-walkers. Janet uses for to pull a wing-nut from one of the dog-walkers. Places it a sanitary table littered with shrapnel: tiny bits of col glass, ball-bearings, parts of razor blades, spent slugs, scraps of unidentified metal.
Sykes still works the two large pieces of trashed iron. U something clicks. The fit. Sykes looks down at the connec metal.
It’s a gurney. Sykes looks down at the mud colored DIGGERS.
Who’s missing an ambulance? Just stares from the Saudis.
Could somebody please go get Sergeant Haytham? Confused stares from the Saudis.  99 100 KINGDOM 8/18/06 97.

(loud) Sergeant Haytham! Inside the crater: water-level down to the ankles. Three Saudis dig around what looks to be one of the dualie-styl back tires. Re-positioning to get a better grip, Sykes notices the top of what looks to be a sizeable, ragged ho still mostly submerged. Pointing:

Here. Sykes slogs over. He drops to his knees, reaches his hand all the way to his shoulder, the side of his face to the water: void. Out of the crater, Sykes points to a Bobcat earth-mover, in Arabic:
Who has the keys?

Janet stands with the Saudi Pathologist. She prepares to a fingerprint from a body. As the moves in to touch the A hand, one of the GUARDS unloads in her direction - a full guttural Arabic assault. No idea what he’s saying, but it obvious he’s furious. Haytham starts firing back. This is un-translated argument. We sense that the guard is doing than expressing his displeasure regarding Janet. This see to be personal. Janet’s getting very nervous. A frighteni display. Then, Haytham turns:
You cannot touch any Muslims. Janet takes a breath as the Police hard-eye her.
No problem. Can I still touch Americans?
Of course. Janet moves back to the American dead, as the Saudi Tech continues with the Muslims. She pulls another shard of COLORED GLASS from a wound.

A two car convoy drives deep into the city. The Convoy is forced to stop across the street from a gas station as a construction crane backs into a drive way. Al-Ghazi and Fleury stare across the street as a large ga truck fills up the heavy tanks of a Saudi gas station.
What’s gas running a gallon out here, Al-Ghazi? Penny gallon? Al-Ghazi smiles.

It was an American. An engineer named Karl Twitchell. Hired by Saudi Arabia to find water. He didn’t find so much as a dried oasis, but he found this. Enough oil to turn the earth. Fleury stares out as the oil spills out overflowing from station tank. COLONEL AL-GHAZI (CONT’D) They say my country sits on over 1 trillion more barrels of recoverable oil.
A trillion reasons for our Leaders to hold hands another one hundred years.
A trillion reasons to keep fighting. For both sides of this War. (beat) I think our oil has begun destroying more than it creates.
Agreed.

I’m 46 years-old. (beat, tired) I have three daughters. And I find myself in a place where I no longer care about ‘why’ we are attacked. I only care that 100 people woke up a few mornings ago had no idea it was their last. When we catch the Man who murdered these people, I don’t care to ask even one question...I just want to kill him...stop him. (beat, a bit embarrassed) Do you understand?
Yes, I do. A long moment. Just road noise. We see two men, as differ from each other as they could be, yet made from the same things. RONALD FLEURY (CONT’D) Is your first name ‘Colonel?’
(a small smile) Faris.

A glazed Haytham works with a Pathologist on the Muslim bodies. Their own collection of foreign objects. Janet pu free 1/2 of a marble from a burrowed hole: explains the shards of colored glass. Cleans it in saline, holds it up the light. We stare at it with her. Janet begins piecing together glass shards - reconstructi MARBLE.

Police Investigators eat lunch under a tent 50 yards away with Leavitt. Then a red laser-sight moves across him: Three MEMBERS of Police security-detail: smirking, pretending to fidget wi an AR-15’s aperture. Leavitt stares. Subtle defiance. Nobody blinks. Silent moments pass.  102 103 104 KINGDOM 8/18/06 100. The smallest of the detail reaches over, pulls the cockin device of the rifle: round in the chamber, so stop lookin us.
Sykes, covered in mud, digging, searching for any signs o identification amongst the charred, mangled metal.

The small convoy pulls up next to a run down, late sevent chunk of architecture which looks like a combination bomb dentist office/ accounting firm. Weird. Two TEENAGERS in pac T-shirts smoke in front. Fleury, Al-Ghazi and a couple of Police head for the blac out front door.
Moving up two flights of stairs. Dark, rundown shredded carpet. Old hip hop - cheap bass, thin speakers. Smoke. Everything grows in intensity as they move up the stairs. more TEENAGERS skulk past.

(half joking to Al-Ghazi) Feel like I’m back home in Detroit. Al-Ghazi keeps moving up and into what is definitely on Fleury’s top ten list of the most bizarre places he’s eve been. FLEURY’S POV: Two rooms: First is some kind of snack/smoke/TV lounge. FILIPINOS serve drinks. Packs of young Saudi MEN drink Co tea, coffee, and smoke. Odd Saudi talk shows mix with hip hop. Behind, another room: bigger, overflowing with stacks of matched computers. Dozens of them. Dozens of Saudi TEENAG plugged in. Head-phoned and mic’d. All chain smoking, all fully plugged in to CALL OF DUTY (an American war game) o line. These kids play with rabid intensity, smoking and screaming and killing.  105 KINGDOM 8/18/06 101. Al-Ghazi moves through the crowd. A small middle aged SAU spots Al-Ghazi. They exchange words. Al-Ghazi waves Fleur follow. Fleury does and follows Al-Ghazi through the computer roo into a back office.
A middle aged Saudi: TALAL. He sits behind a cluttered de Art books and computers everywhere. He gets up and embrac Al-Ghazi. Al-Ghazi then turns to face Fleury.
At one time, Talal was Arafat's senior bomb-maker and planner in the occupied territories. He joined Bin-Laden when Al Qaeda brought the fight to the Royal Family.
(beat) OK. Shouldn’t we arrest him or shoot him or something? Small smile from Al-Ghazi.
He turned himself in last year during an amnesty. He’s now part of a new government effort to balance the experience of Saudi Youth.
This place is community service?
If America figures out a way of keeping their kids off the computers please let us know.
Why did he turn himself in? Before Al-Ghazi can answer, Talal begins talking to him i Arabic. Al-Ghazi translates:
‘You only come after I see there were bombs. (MORE )

Did you know Bin Laden put 5 million-dollars on my head? Why shouldn’t it be 10?’ Subdued laughter. Then Talal becomes quiet, grave. Al-Gha continues the translation: COLONEL AL-GHAZI (CONT’D) The Man who made War on Al-Rahmah is someone my age -- this kind of skill is learned over decades. Talal looks at Fleury now, speaking directly to him throu Al-Ghazi:
A Man who can plan the mass-murder of women and children, then go home at night to his own and sleep soundly...? That kind of Man is supremely difficult to catch.

(through Al-Ghazi) How does he know he slept soundly? Colonel Al-Ghazi hesitates, then relays Fleury’s question Talal stares: eyes touched by war-blood-atrocities commit Someone who believes he’s going to Hell.
(translating) Because he hasn’t stopped. You stop when their faces don’t let you close your eyes...
(through Al-Ghazi) Is that why you quit?

(translating) 17 days without sleep will make you quit anything. Two TEENAGERS stick their heads into the office. They’re about the sharing of a computer. Talal puts a fast stop t it. It’s obvious he’s good with these young boys. He smil as he speaks to Al-Ghazi. Al-Ghazi translates to Fleury.  KINGDOM 8/18/06 103.

He says he makes my job easier. Here, at least they only fight and kill on computers. Al-Ghazi shows Talal the detonator. The old man studies i Al-Ghazi and Talal speak in Arabic about the detonator. Al-Ghazi looks to Fleury, translates.
He says that there are several ways to get American military equipment like this detonator but not many men in Saudi Arabia that know how to get them.
How do they get them?
Usually smuggled from Iraq by corrupt soldiers working with the Americans.
Could Hamza get this equipment? Al-Ghazi asks Talal.
Without question. Yes, he could.
(through Al-Ghazi) How do we find him? He thinks for a moment, then speaks. The boys chuckle as Ghazi continues translating:
Prayer. Luck. Handshakes. Fleury looks at Al-Ghazi, doesn’t quite get it...
(to Al-Ghazi) Well, I think I get the ‘prayer’ and ‘luck’ parts... Talal slowly stands, Al-Ghazi helping him up, moves to Fleury. Reaches his hand out to him, quietly:
+ eH
(translating) His hands will feel like this. Fleury shakes Talal’s hand, turns it over: index finger g
(translating) Every Amir at some point gets bitten by his work.

The Bobcat digs into the crater, over the unknown hole. Already a large pile of dirt. Another sizeable scoop down about two feet: nothing. Haytham now stands over the crat watching Sykes. Leavitt has joined him.
Whatever this is, it blasted-off like NASA. Haytham yells to the Machine Operator in Arabic:
Driven in at an angle... go deeper... Another gouge of earth: 4 feet. Nothing. Grant sits back.

‘High-order explosion’ doesn’t do it justice: what’s left a’ this looks like it was put through a wood-chipper. Leavitt rubs his eyes: adrenaline long gone. Looks at his watch: time passing fast. Sykes drops to his stomach, rea in with the TRENCHING TOOL to see how much farther the ho goes: a metallic ‘clink.

An oxygen tank. The kind used in ambulances. Nozzle assem gone, burst in the explosion with a force that drove it several feet into solid ground. Haytham takes a razor bla scratches off samples of the soil and carbon for explosiv residue into a fresh cannister. Then takes a wet rag, beg cleaning the tank to reveal Arabic script...
(to Sykes) Hospital Identification... Ambulance identification.  107
Do you know this hospital?
Yes.
Call it in.

107 Now a mini command post. Al-Ghazi works phones with Fleur and Mayes by his side. Sykes and Leavitt muddy, sitting o their cots. Leavitt tags evidence from the shootout. Al-Ghazi hangs up, looks to Fleury.
The ambulance was reported stolen from King Fahd Hospital last Wednesday, three days before the bombing.
There’s more: I told you it wouldn’t be hard to find the soldiers.
(focused; to Al-Ghazi) What you got?
The stolen ambulance had a twenty man crew that rotated shifts on it. We checked all twenty men. One of them, Muaath Hazmi is now of interest to us.
Why? Al-Ghazi reaches for the photo of the dead shooter/attack
Because this gentleman is Fathi Hazmi, Muaath’s brother.  108 KINGDOM 8/18/06 106.
Where’s Muaath?
I’m going to show you.

A five block radius has been sealed off by Police Vehicle Fleury and his team are at the outer perimeter, crouched behind barricades at the entrance of a cul-de-sac. They'r not allowed anywhere near the line of fire. They sport bullet-proof vests and helmets: look like reporters in a war-zone. Police turn away cars, neighbors Snipers stand posted on near-by rooftops. Helicopters aud overhead. Street deserted.
We never get to do anything fun.
Sykes, I’m guessing you don’t even remember how to load your gun.
That’s not funny.
She’s not trying to be funny.
I’m a very good shot.
I’m sure. Haytham hands Al-Ghazi a walkie-talkie, in Arabic:
Neighbors clear?
Yes.
Activity or communication?
Snipers have seen nothing. No telephone line into the house.  109 KINGDOM 8/18/06 107.

(beat) Allahuakbar. Go. Two black Suburbans roll around the corner: out-fitted wi running boards and hand rails upon which a 12-man SWAT te rides: 3 on each rail, 2 vehicles. SWAT team: military fatigues, black hoods, Mp-5 close-quarter sub-machine gun Flying down the cul-de-sac: Half-way down the street, one the Snipers open fire: BOOM-BOOM-BOOM. That moment an RPG fires wide of the lead Suburban. Over Al-Ghazi’s walkie- talkie, in Arabic:

The two SWAT-Teamers at the front of the running boards o up with their MP-5s one-handed: the front of the house pu bursts, disintegrates. Suburbans rip to a stop. SWAT off, move fast. Three toss flash grenades into and around the house. Massive flash-bangs. Six through the front door. S sprinting around back. Loud AK-47 bursts from inside now...screams. Then an RPG fired inside: the rushing soun and yellow-white flash past two windows. A section of the left wall of the house detonates from the inside out. More mechanical, silenced thwacks from the SWAT Mp-5s. Silence. Then voices from Al-Ghazi’s walkie-talkie. Ambulances round the corner, fly toward the house:

The team enters, wide-eyed. Four men in civilian garb, al dead: multiple bullet wounds. An Officer with four 8 X 10 shots, matching them to the dead faces, dropping mug-shot respective chests. Once he’s finished, a police photograp takes new pictures of each. At the far side of the House: engineers use 2x4s to support the wall hit with the RPG. of it has the feel of standard Saudi operation procedure. Al-Ghazi appears from the back of the house.
